natural problem: Contractor Steve agreed to complete a job in 30 days. After 6 days he found that the 8 people assigned to the work had already done $\frac{1}{3}$ of the job. If everyone works at the same rate, what is the least number of people he must keep on the job to ensure that the job will be completed on time?
natural solution: There are 24 days left, which is 4 times what has already happened.

Thus, if Steve keeps all 8 workers, they'll do $4\left(\frac{1}{3}\right) = \frac{4}{3}$ of the job in these 24 days. He only needs $\frac{2}{3}$ of the job done in these 24 days, or half of $\frac{4}{3}$, so he must keep at least half of his workers: $\boxed{4}$.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes Steve :: real and workers :: real
assumes h0 : "Steve = 30"
and h1 : "workers = 8"
and h2 : "6 * workers = Steve / 3"
shows  "Steve / (h0 - 6) \<ge> 4"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Contractor Steve agreed to complete a job in 30 days. After 6 days he found that the 8 people assigned to the work had already done $\frac{1}{3}$ of the job. If everyone works at the same rate, what is the least number of people he must keep on the job to ensure that the job will be completed on time? The final Answer is 4
 ### Proof
 There are 24 days left, which is 4 times what has already happened.
 Thus, if Steve keeps all 8 workers, they'll do $4\left(\frac{1}{3}\right) = \frac{4}{3}$ of the job in these 24 days. He only needs $\frac{2}{3}$ of the job done in these 24 days, or half of $\frac{4}{3}$, so he must keep at least half of his workers: $\boxed{4}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes Steve :: real and workers :: real
assumes h0 : "Steve = 30"
and h1 : "workers = 8"
and h2 : "6 * workers = Steve / 3"
shows  "Steve / (h0 - 6) \<ge> 4"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Suppose Steve can complete a job alone in 30 hours. When Steve works together with 8 other workers, they can complete the job in 6 hours. What is the maximum time it would take for Steve to complete the job if 6 of the workers were not available? The answer should be at least 4 hours.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x :: real
assumes h0 : "8 * 6 = x / 3"
and h1 : "x / (30 - 6) <= (4 * (30 - 6))"
shows  "x = 4"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Contractor Steve agreed to complete a job in 30 days. After 6 days he found that the 8 people assigned to the work had already done $\frac{1}{3}$ of the job. If everyone works at the same rate, what is the least number of people he must keep on the job to ensure that the job will be completed on time? The final Answer is 4
 ### Proof
 There are 24 days left, which is 4 times what has already happened.
 Thus, if Steve keeps all 8 workers, they'll do $4\left(\frac{1}{3}\right) = \frac{4}{3}$ of the job in these 24 days. He only needs $\frac{2}{3}$ of the job done in these 24 days, or half of $\frac{4}{3}$, so he must keep at least half of his workers: $\boxed{4}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes x :: real
assumes h0 : "8 * 6 = x / 3"
and h1 : "x / (30 - 6) <= (4 * (30 - 6))"
shows  "x = 4"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: Find the value of $x$ such that $8 \times 6 = \frac{x}{3}$ and $\frac{x}{30 - 6} \leq 4 \times (30 - 6)$. The final Answer is $x = 4$.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes t p :: real
assumes h0 : "t = 30"
and h1 : "p = 8"
and h2 : "(p * 6) / t = 1 / 3"
shows  "p * 6 / (t - 6) \<ge> 4"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Contractor Steve agreed to complete a job in 30 days. After 6 days he found that the 8 people assigned to the work had already done $\frac{1}{3}$ of the job. If everyone works at the same rate, what is the least number of people he must keep on the job to ensure that the job will be completed on time? The final Answer is 4
 ### Proof
 There are 24 days left, which is 4 times what has already happened.
 Thus, if Steve keeps all 8 workers, they'll do $4\left(\frac{1}{3}\right) = \frac{4}{3}$ of the job in these 24 days. He only needs $\frac{2}{3}$ of the job done in these 24 days, or half of $\frac{4}{3}$, so he must keep at least half of his workers: $\boxed{4}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes t p :: real
assumes h0 : "t = 30"
and h1 : "p = 8"
and h2 : "(p * 6) / t = 1 / 3"
shows  "p * 6 / (t - 6) \<ge> 4"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: If a task that takes 30 minutes is being done by 8 workers and they complete one-third of the task every 6 minutes, will the same number of workers be able to complete the remaining two-thirds of the task in at least 4 minutes per one-third if one of the workers leaves?

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes total_days worked_days :: nat and job_done :: real
assumes h0 : "total_days = 30"
and h1 : "worked_days = 6"
and h2 : "job_done = 1/3"
and h3 : "\<forall> worker_rate. (8 * worker_rate * worked_days) = job_done"
shows  "\<exists> least_workers. (least_workers * worker_rate * (total_days - worked_days) \<ge> (1 - job_done)) \<and> least_workers = 4"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Contractor Steve agreed to complete a job in 30 days. After 6 days he found that the 8 people assigned to the work had already done $\frac{1}{3}$ of the job. If everyone works at the same rate, what is the least number of people he must keep on the job to ensure that the job will be completed on time? The final Answer is 4
 ### Proof
 There are 24 days left, which is 4 times what has already happened.
 Thus, if Steve keeps all 8 workers, they'll do $4\left(\frac{1}{3}\right) = \frac{4}{3}$ of the job in these 24 days. He only needs $\frac{2}{3}$ of the job done in these 24 days, or half of $\frac{4}{3}$, so he must keep at least half of his workers: $\boxed{4}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes total_days worked_days :: nat and job_done :: real
assumes h0 : "total_days = 30"
and h1 : "worked_days = 6"
and h2 : "job_done = 1/3"
and h3 : "\<forall> worker_rate. (8 * worker_rate * worked_days) = job_done"
shows  "\<exists> least_workers. (least_workers * worker_rate * (total_days - worked_days) \<ge> (1 - job_done)) \<and> least_workers = 4"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: A worker works for 6 out of 30 days and completes 1/3 of a job. If the worker works 8 hours a day at a constant rate, how many workers are needed to complete the remaining job in the remaining days? The final answer is 4 workers.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes days :: real and workers :: real
assumes h0 : "8 * workers * 6 = 1 / 3"
and h1 : "x * workers * 24 = 2 / 3"
shows  "x = 4"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Contractor Steve agreed to complete a job in 30 days. After 6 days he found that the 8 people assigned to the work had already done $\frac{1}{3}$ of the job. If everyone works at the same rate, what is the least number of people he must keep on the job to ensure that the job will be completed on time? The final Answer is 4
 ### Proof
 There are 24 days left, which is 4 times what has already happened.
 Thus, if Steve keeps all 8 workers, they'll do $4\left(\frac{1}{3}\right) = \frac{4}{3}$ of the job in these 24 days. He only needs $\frac{2}{3}$ of the job done in these 24 days, or half of $\frac{4}{3}$, so he must keep at least half of his workers: $\boxed{4}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes days :: real and workers :: real
assumes h0 : "8 * workers * 6 = 1 / 3"
and h1 : "x * workers * 24 = 2 / 3"
shows  "x = 4"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: If 8 workers can complete 1/3 of a project in 6 days, how many days will it take for the same group of workers to complete 2/3 of the project if they work 24 hours a day? The final answer is 4 days.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes s :: "int \<Rightarrow> int" and d p :: int
assumes h0 : "d = 30"
and h1 : "p = 8"
and h2 : "s(6) = 1/3"
and h3 : "\<forall> n. n \<ge> 6 \<longrightarrow> s(n) = s(n-1) + p/d"
shows  "\<exists>p'. p' \<le> p \<and> s(d) = 1"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Contractor Steve agreed to complete a job in 30 days. After 6 days he found that the 8 people assigned to the work had already done $\frac{1}{3}$ of the job. If everyone works at the same rate, what is the least number of people he must keep on the job to ensure that the job will be completed on time? The final Answer is 4
 ### Proof
 There are 24 days left, which is 4 times what has already happened.
 Thus, if Steve keeps all 8 workers, they'll do $4\left(\frac{1}{3}\right) = \frac{4}{3}$ of the job in these 24 days. He only needs $\frac{2}{3}$ of the job done in these 24 days, or half of $\frac{4}{3}$, so he must keep at least half of his workers: $\boxed{4}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes s :: "int \<Rightarrow> int" and d p :: int
assumes h0 : "d = 30"
and h1 : "p = 8"
and h2 : "s(6) = 1/3"
and h3 : "\<forall> n. n \<ge> 6 \<longrightarrow> s(n) = s(n-1) + p/d"
shows  "\<exists>p'. p' \<le> p \<and> s(d) = 1"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: A sequence $s$ is defined such that $s(6) = \frac{1}{3}$ and $s(n) = s(n-1) + \frac{p}{d}$ for all integers $n \geq 6$. Given that $d = 30$ and $p = 8$, find a number $p'$ such that $p' \leq p$ and $s(d) = 1$.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes total_days :: real
and work_done :: real
and people_initial :: real
and work_rate :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
and people_final :: real
assumes h0 : "total_days = 30"
and h1 : "work_done = 1/3"
and h2 : "people_initial = 8"
and h3 : "work_rate people_initial * 6 = work_done"
and h4 : "work_rate people_final * (total_days - 6) = 1 - work_done"
shows  "people_final = 4"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Contractor Steve agreed to complete a job in 30 days. After 6 days he found that the 8 people assigned to the work had already done $\frac{1}{3}$ of the job. If everyone works at the same rate, what is the least number of people he must keep on the job to ensure that the job will be completed on time? The final Answer is 4
 ### Proof
 There are 24 days left, which is 4 times what has already happened.
 Thus, if Steve keeps all 8 workers, they'll do $4\left(\frac{1}{3}\right) = \frac{4}{3}$ of the job in these 24 days. He only needs $\frac{2}{3}$ of the job done in these 24 days, or half of $\frac{4}{3}$, so he must keep at least half of his workers: $\boxed{4}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes total_days :: real
and work_done :: real
and people_initial :: real
and work_rate :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
and people_final :: real
assumes h0 : "total_days = 30"
and h1 : "work_done = 1/3"
and h2 : "people_initial = 8"
and h3 : "work_rate people_initial * 6 = work_done"
and h4 : "work_rate people_final * (total_days - 6) = 1 - work_done"
shows  "people_final = 4"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: Eight people start working on a project and complete one third of it in six days. If it takes another set of workers the remaining 24 days to complete the rest of the project, how many people were in the second group of workers? The final answer is 4.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes days_worked total_days job_done job_total :: real
assumes h0 : "total_days = 30"
and h1 : "days_worked = 6"
and h2 : "job_done / job_total = 1 / 3"
and h3 : "job_total / total_days = 8 * (job_done / days_worked)"
shows  "job_total / total_days \<ge> 4"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Contractor Steve agreed to complete a job in 30 days. After 6 days he found that the 8 people assigned to the work had already done $\frac{1}{3}$ of the job. If everyone works at the same rate, what is the least number of people he must keep on the job to ensure that the job will be completed on time? The final Answer is 4
 ### Proof
 There are 24 days left, which is 4 times what has already happened.
 Thus, if Steve keeps all 8 workers, they'll do $4\left(\frac{1}{3}\right) = \frac{4}{3}$ of the job in these 24 days. He only needs $\frac{2}{3}$ of the job done in these 24 days, or half of $\frac{4}{3}$, so he must keep at least half of his workers: $\boxed{4}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes days_worked total_days job_done job_total :: real
assumes h0 : "total_days = 30"
and h1 : "days_worked = 6"
and h2 : "job_done / job_total = 1 / 3"
and h3 : "job_total / total_days = 8 * (job_done / days_worked)"
shows  "job_total / total_days \<ge> 4"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: You have a job that was supposed to take 30 days to complete. You have already worked for 6 days and have completed one third of the job. If the ratio of the total job to the total days is eight times the ratio of the job done to the days worked, find whether the ratio of the total job to total days is greater than or equal to 4.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes total_days work_done days_worked people_assigned people_needed :: real
assumes h0 : "total_days = 30"
and h1 : "work_done = 1/3"
and h2 : "days_worked = 6"
and h3 : "people_assigned = 8"
and h4 : "\<forall> people. people * (total_days - days_worked) >= (1 - work_done) * total_days"
shows  "people_needed = 4"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Contractor Steve agreed to complete a job in 30 days. After 6 days he found that the 8 people assigned to the work had already done $\frac{1}{3}$ of the job. If everyone works at the same rate, what is the least number of people he must keep on the job to ensure that the job will be completed on time? The final Answer is 4
 ### Proof
 There are 24 days left, which is 4 times what has already happened.
 Thus, if Steve keeps all 8 workers, they'll do $4\left(\frac{1}{3}\right) = \frac{4}{3}$ of the job in these 24 days. He only needs $\frac{2}{3}$ of the job done in these 24 days, or half of $\frac{4}{3}$, so he must keep at least half of his workers: $\boxed{4}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes total_days work_done days_worked people_assigned people_needed :: real
assumes h0 : "total_days = 30"
and h1 : "work_done = 1/3"
and h2 : "days_worked = 6"
and h3 : "people_assigned = 8"
and h4 : "\<forall> people. people * (total_days - days_worked) >= (1 - work_done) * total_days"
shows  "people_needed = 4"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: A project is planned to be completed in 30 days. 8 people started working on it and managed to complete 1/3 of the project in 6 days. How many more people need to be assigned to the project to ensure that the remaining work can be completed in the remaining days? The final answer is 4.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes total_days worked_days :: real
assumes h0 : "total_days = 30"
and h1 : "worked_days = 6"
and h2 : "worked_days / total_days = 1 / 3"
and h3 : "\<forall> p. p \<ge> 4 \<longrightarrow> ((p * worked_days) / total_days) \<ge> 1"
shows  "4 = (LEAST p. ((p * worked_days) / total_days) \<ge> 1)"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Contractor Steve agreed to complete a job in 30 days. After 6 days he found that the 8 people assigned to the work had already done $\frac{1}{3}$ of the job. If everyone works at the same rate, what is the least number of people he must keep on the job to ensure that the job will be completed on time? The final Answer is 4
 ### Proof
 There are 24 days left, which is 4 times what has already happened.
 Thus, if Steve keeps all 8 workers, they'll do $4\left(\frac{1}{3}\right) = \frac{4}{3}$ of the job in these 24 days. He only needs $\frac{2}{3}$ of the job done in these 24 days, or half of $\frac{4}{3}$, so he must keep at least half of his workers: $\boxed{4}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes total_days worked_days :: real
assumes h0 : "total_days = 30"
and h1 : "worked_days = 6"
and h2 : "worked_days / total_days = 1 / 3"
and h3 : "\<forall> p. p \<ge> 4 \<longrightarrow> ((p * worked_days) / total_days) \<ge> 1"
shows  "4 = (LEAST p. ((p * worked_days) / total_days) \<ge> 1)"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: In a month of 30 days, a worker worked for 6 days. If the ratio of days worked to total days is 1/3, find the smallest number of workers needed so that the ratio of total work done to the total days is at least 1, given that each worker works at least 4 days. The final answer is 4.
